text: On Friday morning, a landslide buried 83 workers in a mining area in the Tibet Autonomous Region. The incident occurred in Maizhokunggar County, east of Lhasa, at around 6 a.m. The victims were workers from Tibet Huatailong Mining Development Co. Ltd., a subsidiary of the China National Gold Group Corp. The landslide, which was made up of about 2 million cubic meters of mud, rock, and other debris, was caused by heavy rain. The local government has confirmed the incident and is investigating the cause. The workers included two Tibetans.

Libyan and U.S. officials held face-to-face talks in Tunisia over the weekend, but Washington's sole point of the meeting was to repeat its demand that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi "must go". Libyan government spokesman Musa Ibrahim called the talks "a first step" and stated that the two sides were ready to discuss ideas to end the conflict and repair the damaged relationship between Libya and the U.S. However, a U.S. official familiar with the meeting said the purpose was "for us to convey directly that Gadhafi must go". NATO has been bombing Libya under a U.N. mandate to protect civilians from Gadhafi's forces, who are battling a rebellion that has claimed control of the eastern half of the country. Despite previous reports of talks between the rebels and the government, Libyan rebels have denied any such talks.

Canada has officially renounced the Kyoto Protocol, a treaty aimed at reducing greenhouse gas emissions blamed for a warming climate. The Conservative government, led by Prime Minister Stephen Harper, has long opposed the treaty and refused to implement it since taking office in 2006. Canada's Environment Minister, Peter Kent, said the previous government signed onto the treaty "without any regard to how it would be fulfilled," and that Canadians faced "radical" cuts or financial penalties equivalent to $1,600 per family. Canada is "well on our way" to reducing emissions by 17% over 2005 levels by 2020, but critics say that self-imposed goal is well below the Kyoto targets. International negotiators agreed to extend the limits of the treaty last weekend, and launched an effort to set up a broader pact with a legal format to curb carbon emissions. The talks also launched a Green Climate Fund, which would essentially channel about $100 billion by 2020 to vulnerable countries to help them deal with the effects of climate change.

Faezeh Hashemi, daughter of Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, has begun serving a six-month sentence at Evin prison in Iran for making anti-government statements. She was arrested last year for taking part in protests and was sentenced in January, just before parliamentary elections. Her father, a former president and powerful cleric, has been a vocal critic of the government and a staunch opponent of President Ahmadinejad.

The "Barefoot Bandit," Colton Harris-Moore, appeared in court and pleaded not guilty to six federal charges. His attorney, John Henry Browne, stated that negotiations for a plea agreement are underway, and a draft could be finished by the end of the day. Browne added that the restitution amount is still being determined, and any money generated from book or movie deals will go to the victims. Harris-Moore, who has a loyal fan base, is accused of stealing boats, cars, and planes while eluding police capture. His trial is scheduled for July 11.

In April 2006, Hashim Ibrahim Awad, a 52-year-old Iraqi civilian, was killed in Hamdaniya, Iraq. Seven Marines and a Navy medic were charged in connection with his death. Cpl. Trent D. Thomas, a member of Kilo Company, 3rd Battalion, 5th Marine Regiment, was found guilty of kidnapping and conspiracy to commit several offenses, including murder, larceny, housebreaking, kidnapping, and making false official statements.

Thomas will be demoted to the rank of entry-level private and receive a bad-conduct discharge. Sgt. Lawrence G. Hutchins III, the squad leader, is accused of dragging Awad from his home, shooting him in the street, and then making it look like he had planned to ambush American troops. Hutchins has pleaded not guilty to murder, conspiracy, and other charges and faces a sentence of life in prison if convicted.

Thomas initially pleaded guilty but later changed his plea to not guilty, claiming that he had followed orders. He apologized for his role in the killing, and his sentence could have been life in prison. The group's leader, Hutchins, awaits trial on murder and conspiracy charges.

A poultry facility in southwest Missouri has been quarantined due to a suspected case of bird flu, with additional tests to confirm the virus's presence. Owner Cargill will euthanize up to 15,000 turkeys exposed to antibodies from older birds. Missouri officials emphasize that humans are rarely affected by this type of bird flu. Test results may be available as early as Friday, with tests being conducted on flocks within a six-mile radius.

A French mayoral candidate, Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet, has suggested transforming Paris' disused metro stations into swimming pools, nightclubs, and restaurants. She has commissioned illustrations of one such station, Arsenal, which has been vacant since 1939, to showcase the potential uses. There are a total of 16 disused metro stations beneath Paris, with most closed between the 1930s and 1970s. The candidate is asking for public input on the best use for these spaces, with the most popular idea being a theater. Although Kosciusko-Morizet is not the frontrunner in the mayoral race, the images have generated interest in the project.

David Headley, born Daood Gilani, changed his name in 2006 to cooperate with terrorism plots, including the 2008 Mumbai attacks. He was sentenced to 35 years in prison after pleading guilty to the attacks. He received a Social Security number in the late 1970s, and his cooperation helped authorities in the investigation of the Danish newspaper terror plot and the Mumbai attacks. Headley attended Lashkar-e-Tayyiba's terrorism training camps and plotted attacks. He was arrested in 2009 for the Mumbai attacks and has been extradited to India for trial. The United States has not agreed to send him to any other country for trial.

Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy condemned a deadly attack on soldiers at a checkpoint in Sinai, vowing to capture the perpetrators. At least 15 Egyptian soldiers were killed and nine others wounded when masked assailants attacked as the soldiers were breaking their Ramadan fast. Israel's Defense Forces blamed Global Jihad terrorists for the violence, stating they had captured an Egyptian military post, killed over 10 Egyptian soldiers, and taken over two armored personnel carriers. The Rafah border crossing has been closed indefinitely, and more military forces have been deployed to assist. Morsy called for an emergency meeting and reiterated that Sinai is safe and under control.

A bomb blast in Kano, Nigeria killed at least four people, causing several cars to burn. The attack happened in a predominantly Christian area of the city. The police spokesman said it was not immediately clear who was responsible for the attack, but recent terrorism in Nigeria has drawn global attention, including the kidnapping of over 200 school girls by Boko Haram.

Space shuttle Discovery is set to launch next week on a mission to the international space station. The launch is scheduled for 1:36 a.m. ET Tuesday. The crew will include seven astronauts, and one of them, Nicole Stott, will remain on the space station as a flight engineer. The space station's newest compartment will be named Tranquility, after a suggestion by comedian Stephen Colbert who urged his viewers to suggest "Colbert" for the name, which won. The treadmill that will be delivered to the space station is named after Colbert and is called the Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill (COLBERT).

Six unidentified men were found hiding in a cargo truck at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport during a security sweep. The men, who were illegal immigrants, were handed over to federal agencies for further investigation. None of the men had access to secure areas of the airport, and they did not pose a threat to the United States. The investigation is ongoing, and the men have not yet been processed for removal from the country. The security operation was part of a routine exercise conducted randomly at various transportation hubs.

Lt. Gen. Karl Eikenberry, a career military officer, is seeking Senate confirmation to become the next U.S. Ambassador to Afghanistan. If approved, he hopes to bring his wife, Ching Eikenberry, with him. However, Afghanistan is designated as an "unaccompanied post" by the State Department due to the dangers of the war and terror attacks, meaning family members are not allowed. Sen. John Kerry, who was running Eikenberry's confirmation hearing, expressed support for the idea, saying it would be a boost of morale for the Embassy.

First Lady Michelle Obama will campaign in Iowa for Democratic candidate Bruce Braley, who is running to replace retiring Democratic Senator Tom Harkin. This will be her second appearance on the campaign trail. Braley is facing Republican state Senator Joni Ernst, who has gained momentum with endorsements from notable Republicans. Obama's appearance may help boost Braley's chances, as the race is currently considered a close one. Despite low approval ratings for President Obama in Iowa, the first lady will campaign where her husband cannot. This weekend, former President Bill Clinton and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton will both appear at retiring Democratic Senator Tom Harkin's annual Steak Fry, but neither has plans to stump specifically for Braley.

Anes Subasic, a Bosnian-born U.S. citizen from North Carolina, was found guilty of conspiracy to murder people overseas and providing material support to terrorists. He is the seventh member of a terrorist group in North Carolina, led by Daniel Boyd, who pleaded guilty in 2011. Two of Boyd's sons also pleaded guilty and are in prison. Subasic was part of a group that provided money, weapons training, transportation, and personnel to "advance violent jihad" from November 2006 until at least July 2009. He was also found guilty of illegally obtaining citizenship in a separate trial. The case involved a conspiracy to commit violent acts against U.S. service members and others abroad.

A Canadian woman with a disability recently bungee jumped off a bridge and into an icy river below. Christine Rougoor, who has been in a wheelchair since a motocross accident in 2008, won a contest sponsored by an adventure company that helps people with disabilities achieve extreme sports dreams. Rougoor won an all-expenses-paid trip to Whistler, British Columbia, for snowmobiling and bungee jumping and won by submitting a video of her shooting guns, riding high-tech bikes for paraplegics, and playing tennis in her wheelchair. The group's founder, Karim Ladki, warns first-time jumpers to stay in their chairs to prevent blackouts and encouraged Rougoor to go for it. The bungee jump provided a few seconds of freedom for Rougoor, who wants to do it again and again.

The 2014 midterm elections resulted in a significant victory for the Republican party, with their largest congressional majority since World War II. In addition to the political achievements, several firsts were also recorded at the individual level. Tim Scott became the first African-American from the South elected to the Senate since Reconstruction and the first African-American to be elected to both the House and the Senate. Mia Love became the first black Republican woman elected to Congress and the first Haitian-American to serve in Congress. Joni Ernst became the first woman to represent Iowa in Congress and the first female combat veteran elected to the Senate. Shelley Moore Capito won the Senate seat for the first woman elected to the Senate from West Virginia. Tom Cotton became the first Iraq War and Afghanistan war veteran elected to the Senate. Gina Raimondo will be the first female governor of Rhode Island. Elise Stefanik, at 30, became the youngest woman elected to Congress.

On Monday in western Afghanistan, a helicopter crash killed 10 Americans, including seven U.S. service members and three U.S. civilians. The crash occurred after the helicopter took off following a successful operation to disrupt arms smuggling and narcotics trafficking in Qadis district. The Army stated that low visibility due to dust from the initial takeoff was to blame for the crash. Militants did not fire at the helicopter during the departure or crash. The crash was one of two incidents that day involving helicopters, and in the other crash four U.S. service members died when two helicopters collided in the air in southern Afghanistan.

In 1977, a 16-year-old girl in Louisiana gave birth to a boy and gave him up for adoption. The boy's mother searched for him over the years without success, but eventually moved to Shreveport, Louisiana with her other children. Her daughter, Candace Eloph, never stopped searching and eventually found her half-brother, Jamie Wheat, living across the street from her. They discovered that their mothers were both only 16 years old when they gave birth to them, and they took a DNA test that showed a 99.995% probability of them being related. The two brothers, who had never met before, are now reunited and excited to make up for lost time.

When CNN interviews George Clinton, they wonder if they should salute him with an "Atomic Dog" bark or hug him. Clinton, a 70-year-old musician, greets them warmly. Clinton is known for rebranding his bands and changing with the times, having hits every 10 years. He credits his numerous bandmates, including Bootsy Collins and Gary Shider, for his success. Clinton also talks about fighting piracy and the importance of not telling kids not to do something. He says he may have made better decisions if he had been on top of his game, but he remains healthy, energetic, and plans to continue doing what he loves.

Queen Beatrix of the Netherlands will abdicate her throne on April 30, 2013. She made the decision to step down after 33 years on the throne, to allow her son, Prince Willem-Alexander, to succeed her. Queen Beatrix emphasized that she will still be active and will meet with the public. Under the Dutch Constitution, the king or queen serves as the head of state but is politically neutral. Queen Beatrix thanked the Dutch people for their support and said that her son and daughter-in-law, Princess Maxima, are fully prepared to take on their new roles. The Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte praised Queen Beatrix for her knowledge, experience, and involvement in the country.

A prominent Texas attorney, Marco Antonio Delgado, is facing charges of laundering over $600 million for a Mexican drug cartel. He was arrested at a restaurant in El Paso and has been accused of conspiring to launder more than $600 million. Delgado was a former university trustee and had been active in the local community, including setting up a scholarship for Latino students at Carnegie Mellon University. If convicted, he faces a maximum of 20 years in prison.

Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez ordered an investigation into the death of Simon Bolivar, a former military leader, after exhuming his skeletal remains. Chavez suspects Bolivar may have been murdered and called for a DNA test to be performed on the remains and clothing items found inside the tomb. Bolivar, who died in 1830, is credited with leading armies that liberated several Latin American nations and spreading democratic principles in the region. Chavez, who has described Bolivar as "the father of the revolution," cried when he first saw the remains.

Four people were killed and nine injured in Saudi Arabia in clashes between unknown criminal sources and Shiite protesters in the Qatif region of Eastern Province. The protesters were calling for the release of prisoners and more rights, and were urging the withdrawal of regional forces from Bahrain. Interior Ministry spokesman Mansur al-Turki blamed "unknown criminal sources" for the violence. The cause of the unrest is not specified but it is believed to be connected to tensions between Iran and the Sunni world, as well as the situation in nearby Bahrain.

A wildfire in Michigan's Upper Peninsula has destroyed 97 structures, including homes, hotels, stores, and motels, since it started last Wednesday. The Duck Lake Fire has burned over 22,000 acres and is currently 51% contained. Despite recent rains, firefighters continue to work on containing the blaze, which is believed to have been caused by lightning. At least 34 homes, a hotel, a store, and other structures have been destroyed. The fire's south end is about 14 miles north of Newberry and 7 miles west of Yahquamenon Falls State Park campgrounds, but a lack of roads in the area has made fighting the fire difficult.

A Kickstarter campaign to make potato salad has raised over $5,000 with over 850 backers. The campaign was started by Zack Brown, who set a modest goal of $10. He has no prior experience making potato salad, but the campaign's absurdity and mundanity have resonated with potential investors. For a $20 pledge, backers receive a potato-salad themed haiku written by Brown and a signed jar of mayonnaise. The goal has since been increased to invite the "entire Internet" to a party to taste the potato salad.

Kanye West asked concertgoers in Sydney to stand before he continued with his performance. He made the demand twice, and when two people didn't stand, he questioned their ability to do so. He eventually allowed them to sit, but only if they were in wheelchairs. The stunt led to criticism on Twitter, as it wasn't the first time West made this demand.

The vanishing spray, used by referees at the FIFA World Cup, is now being used in the English Premier League. The biodegradable foam helps referees mark the 10-yard distance for free kicks, preventing defenders from encroaching. The Premier League made the decision to use the spray after consulting with clubs and referees. The spray will be used for the first time in a match between Manchester United and Swansea City on August 16. Mike Riley, the general manager of the Premier League refereeing body, welcomed the addition. The spray has been used in Major League Soccer for several years and was a hit with players and fans at the 2014 World Cup in Brazil.

Nine people died on a crashed jet near Freeport on Grand Bahama. The cause of the crash is not yet known, and the Federal Aviation Administration is investigating. The victims include the senior pastor of Bahamas Faith Ministries International Fellowship, Myles Munroe, and his wife, Ruth. They were scheduled speakers at a conference starting Monday, but it will continue as planned. The Global Leadership Forum will continue despite the crash, as it was Dr. Munroe's wish. The ITWLA, founded by Munroe, confirms this. The former U.S. ambassador to the United Nations, Andrew Young, also confirms that Myles and Ruth Munroe were among the victims.

The United States Tennis Association (USTA) announced that Arthur Ashe Stadium, the largest stadium at the U.S. Open, will have a retractable roof as early as 2016, ending the weather-related issues that have plagued the event in recent years. The Australian Open and Wimbledon already have retractable roofs. The USTA also plans to build a new, bigger Louis Armstrong Stadium and Grandstand Court, with a retractable roof on Louis Armstrong expected to be completed by 2018. The project is estimated to cost $550 million, with both stadiums being roughly 50 years old. The cost of the retractable roof over Arthur Ashe is expected to exceed $100 million. Players, including women's No. 1 Serena Williams, welcome the news, which will likely mean the tournament won't enter a 15th day. However, players like Andy Murray have concerns about transitioning from indoors to outdoors. Frenchman Jo-Wilfried Tsonga has pulled out of this year's U.S. Open due to a knee injury.

A massive landslide buried 83 workers in a mining area in the Tibet Autonomous Region on Friday morning. The incident occurred in Maizhokunggar County, east of Lhasa, and involved workers from Tibet Huatailong Mining Development Co. Ltd., a subsidiary of the China National Gold Group Corp. The landslide was estimated to have been made up of about 2 million cubic meters of mud, rock, and debris. The victims, including two Tibetans, were all workers. The incident occurred around 6 a.m.

Libyan and US officials held face-to-face talks in Tunisia over the weekend, but Washington's sole point of the meeting was to repeat its demand that Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi "must go." The disclosure came nearly four months into the bombardment of Libya by NATO allies, including the United States. Libyan government spokesman Musa Ibrahim called Saturday's talks "a first step," adding that Washington was ready to discuss ideas to end the conflict and repair the damaged relationship between Libya and the US. However, a U.S. official familiar with the meeting said the purpose of the meeting was "for us to convey directly that Gadhafi must go." The official added that the three-hour session in Tunis was a "one-time meeting to send a clear message" and not the start of negotiations. NATO has been bombing Libya under a U.N. mandate to protect civilians from troops loyal to Gadhafi, who is battling a rebellion that has claimed control of the eastern half of the country. After Friday's announcement that the United States would recognize the rebel movement based in Benghazi as Libya's rightful government, the US wanted to tell the Libyans face-to-face what it has been saying publicly: that Gadhafi must go. The State Department official said talks involved three American envoys and four Libyan officials. One of the Americans was the US ambassador to Libya, Gene Cretz. Ibrahim said in June that Libya would not consider a peace initiative that would require Gadhafi to step down.

Canada has officially renounced the Kyoto Protocol, a day after international negotiators agreed to extend the treaty's limits on carbon emissions. Environment Minister Peter Kent stated that Canada would keep working to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions and help negotiate a new framework for a global pact. However, the Conservative government, led by Prime Minister Stephen Harper, has long opposed the Kyoto protocol and refused to implement it since taking office in 2006. The opposition accused the government of standing up for big polluters and risking Canada's reputation by abandoning the 1997 treaty. Canada had announced in 2010 that it would fall well short of the treaty's target and that Canadians faced "radical" cuts or financial penalties equivalent to $1,600 per family. The government has said it is "well on its way" to reducing emissions by 17% over 2005 levels by 2020, but critics argue that this goal is well below the Kyoto targets. The talks in Durban also launched a Green Climate Fund, which would essentially channel about $100 billion by 2020 to vulnerable countries to help them deal with the effects of climate change.

Faezeh Hashemi, the daughter of former Iranian President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, has been arrested and sentenced to six months in prison for making anti-government statements. She arrived at Evin prison, a notorious facility in Tehran, to begin her sentence. Hashemi was arrested last year for taking part in anti-government protests, and her father is a powerful cleric and former parliament speaker who has been a vocal critic of the government in the past. Despite his past criticisms, he has toned down his rhetoric in recent years and made statements of apparent support for the regime and its leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei. Hashemi's arrest comes amidst ongoing political tensions in Iran and weeks after the country held parliamentary elections.

Malaysia Airlines is facing another public relations and financial blow after the loss of Flight 17, a Boeing 777 that crashed in eastern Ukraine on Thursday. The airline has lost contact with the flight, coded MH17, and its last known position was over Ukrainian airspace. The company's main shareholder was reportedly considering a restructuring of the operation and taking it private. Malaysia Airlines has faced intense criticism over its handling of Flight 370, which disappeared in March 2014. The airline has also struggled financially, with a loss of about $1.3 billion over the past three years. The financial troubles of the airline have forced the government to step in to provide temporary relief. The crash of Flight 17 is a potential fatal event for the airline, but it also presents an opportunity for the company to redeem itself in how it deals with information and the public.

A UFO caused a wind turbine blade in Lincolnshire, UK to fall off, according to the Sun newspaper. Locals reported seeing strange lights in the sky before the incident, which the Ministry of Defence has yet to explain. However, the Guardian reports that the lights were actually fireworks from a family celebration. The blade may have come off due to a mechanical failure or cold weather.

Summary: Strange lights in sky lead to missing wind turbine blade. UFO blamed by Sun newspaper, but explained as fireworks by Guardian. Possible mechanical failure or cold weather cause.

Relevance: The story highlights the mystery surrounding the incident, the blame placed on a UFO, and the subsequent explanation. The report also covers the possibility of a mechanical failure or weather-related cause.

The "Barefoot Bandit," Colton Harris-Moore, pleaded not guilty to six federal charges during a court appearance on Thursday. His lawyer, John Henry Browne, stated that attorneys are working on a plea agreement and stressed that any money generated from book or movie deals should go to the victims. Harris-Moore, who has a loyal fan base on Facebook, was arrested in the Bahamas in 2010 for stealing a plane and escaping from a Washington group home in 2008. His trial is scheduled for July 11.

A Marine, Cpl. Trent D. Thomas, was sentenced to a reduction in rank and discharge after being found guilty of kidnapping and conspiracy to commit several offenses, including murder, in connection to the death of an Iraqi civilian in 2006. Thomas, who had originally pleaded guilty to the charges, changed his plea to not guilty in February and argued that he had merely followed orders. The case involves seven Marines and a Navy medic who were accused of killing Hashim Ibrahim Awad, 52, and the squad leader, Sgt. Lawrence G. Hutchins III, is facing trial for murder and conspiracy charges.

A poultry facility in southwest Missouri has been quarantined after a suspected case of bird flu was discovered during routine testing. The Missouri Department of Agriculture stated that the facility has been quarantined as a precaution. Additional tests are being conducted to confirm the viral disease, but it is extremely rare for humans to be affected by this type of bird flu. Cargill Corp. has stated that it will euthanize up to 15,000 younger birds exposed to older turkeys that tested positive for bird flu antibodies. The older birds are being harvested at another location, and their meat poses no health risk. Flocks within six miles of the facility are being tested, and test results may be back as early as Friday. The US Agriculture Department is monitoring the situation.

A mayoral candidate in Paris has proposed transforming the city's disused metro stations into unique spaces, such as nightclubs, swimming pools, and restaurants. French candidate Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet has commissioned illustrations showcasing 16 disused metro stations, including the Arsenal station, which could be used for aquatic and artistic purposes. While her ideas are intriguing, she lies far behind the favorite candidate, Anne Hidalgo, in the mayoral race. Despite this, the images have garnered attention in the local press.

The trial of Kaing Guek Eav, known as Duch, resumed in Cambodia on Monday for his role as the former prison chief during the Khmer Rouge regime. Prosecutors painted a grim picture of the torture and killing of more than 15,000 people by the regime, with Duch accused of actively participating in some of the atrocities. Duch faces charges of crimes against humanity, war crimes, torture, and murder. The trial is significant as it is the first time a former Khmer Rouge leader is standing trial, with four former leaders also awaiting trial. Duch's trial is taking place outside Phnom Penh and many of the victims of the regime are survivors of the abuse who watched the proceedings from an auditorium. The trial is expected to last three or four months, with prosecutors arguing that Duch's actions had a significant impact on the lives of many. Duch has admitted his role in the Khmer Rouge's genocidal reign, and the trial is seen as a way of ensuring that those responsible for the crimes committed under the regime face justice.

David Headley, born Daood Gilani, received a 35-year prison sentence for his role in the 2008 Mumbai attacks that killed 164 people, including six US citizens. He had changed his name to David Headley in 2006 to facilitate surveillance in India. He cooperated with US authorities, providing valuable intelligence on terrorist activities. He was arrested for planning terror attacks against a Danish newspaper that sparked Muslim anger worldwide. Headley testified against a Canadian man who was sentenced to 14 years in prison. The Indian government wants to conduct another trial, but the US has said Headley will not be sent to any other country.

Keywords: David Headley, Mumbai attacks, terrorism, cooperation, prison sentence, surveillance, intelligence, terror plot, Danish newspaper, Lashkar-e-Tayyiba, Gary Shapiro, US attorney, Algeria, cooperation, US government, terror landscape, 2008, 35 years, life sentence, prosecutors, six US citizens, Pakistan, surveillance, conviction, Daood Gilani, Philadelphia, 2006, Social Security number, terrorism training camps, Lashkar, Mumbai attacks, Indian government, Gary Shapiro, US attorney, Chicago, 2009, Gary Shapiro, acting US attorney, Chicago, Gary Shapiro, US attorney, Gary Shapiro, Chicago, Gary Shapiro, US attorney, Chicago, Gary Shapiro, US attorney, Chicago, Gary Shapiro, US attorney, Chicago, Gary Shapiro, US attorney, Chicago, Gary Shapiro, US attorney, Chicago, Gary Shapiro.

Egyptian President Mohamed Morsy condemned a deadly attack on Egyptian soldiers at a military checkpoint in the Sinai border, vowing to capture the perpetrators. At least 15 soldiers were killed and nine others injured on Sunday when masked assailants attacked them as they were breaking their Ramadan fast. The Israel Defense Forces blamed terrorists associated with the Global Jihad group for the violence. The attackers captured an Egyptian military post and took over two armored personnel carriers, one of which exploded at the border. The Rafah border crossing has been closed indefinitely, and more military forces have been deployed to the area. Morsy called for an emergency meeting of the military council and asked for the closure of all border tunnels connecting Gaza with Egypt. Hamas officials also closed the tunnels following the attack.

A bomb blast in Kano, a predominantly Christian area of northern Nigeria, killed at least four people on Sunday evening. The blast occurred at a busy intersection, and several cars were burning. The police cordoned off the area and were searching for suspects and any additional bombs. The attack comes at a time when terrorism in Nigeria has been in the global spotlight since more than 200 school girls were kidnapped by Boko Haram. The terror group abducted an estimated 276 girls on April 14 from a boarding school in Chibok in northeastern Nigeria. Dozens escaped, but more than 200 girls are still missing.

Humans have a diverse relationship with food, as evidenced by unusual food festivals worldwide. Food festivals celebrate food, wrestle in it, wage war with it, idolize it, and even race it down a hill. Spam is an unusual favorite in Hawaii, where it is consumed more than in any other U.S. state, and is celebrated at the Waikiki Spam Jam. Foods at festivals range from mundane to daring, such as road kill in West Virginia or scorpions in North Carolina. Some festivals even demand participants get dirty, like the mashed potato wrestling competition at Barnesville, Minnesota's Potato Days. In Bessieres, France, the town makes a giant omelet every Easter to feed the poor, and in Abbeville, Louisiana, the town has their own version of the tradition, adding local ingredients. In Switzerland, locals create elaborate floats using hollowed-out turnips at the Räbechilbi Turnip Festival. The atmosphere is peaceful, but don't eat the turnips, as it's not good for your stomach.

Space shuttle Discovery is set to launch next week on a mission to the international space station, NASA announced. The space shuttle will carry a crew of seven astronauts and deliver the Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill (COLBERT), named after Stephen Colbert, to the space station. The treadmill was named through an online poll, and Colbert suggested "Colbert" which won. The mission will be the 37th for Discovery and the 30th dedicated to assembly and maintenance of the space station.

Google has announced a new version of its Google Glass, an entry into the world of wearable tech, which will be released next year. The new version of Glass will work with eyeglasses or shades and will include an ear bud to replace the bone-conduction speaker. The current model has been faulted by some testers, and the new version will be available to current testers starting this Friday. The current testers will also have the opportunity to invite three friends to the program, and the new version will cost $1,500. Google has not revealed the design changes, but it is expected that users will be able to insert prescription lenses into the device. The new version of Glass is the second generation and is expected to be a groundbreaker in the wearable tech market, with Samsung, Apple, and others expected to join the smartwatch market soon.

Six unidentified men were found in a cargo truck at Atlanta's Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport during a random security sweep. The Transportation Security Administration, along with federal and state agencies, were conducting counter-terrorism exercises when the men were discovered. The men were handed over to two federal agencies, Customs and Border Protection and Immigration and Customs Enforcement. ICE spokeswoman Barbara Gonzalez said the men were illegal immigrants and none of them had access to secure areas of the airport. Gonzalez later clarified that the men had not yet been processed for removal from the United States and there is an ongoing investigation. The security operation took place outside a cargo facility that has no connection to any airport terminals and was part of a routine exercise carried out randomly at various transportation hubs.

The Catholic Church has approximately 600 million female members, but none will have a direct say in the election of the next pope, who will be a man. According to legend, a ninth-century Englishwoman disguised herself as a priest to become the Pope, but historian Diarmaid MacCulloch says the story is a myth. The legend has been used to boost the cause of women priests, but MacCulloch warns that it is dangerous to use a patently nonsense story to promote a good cause. While women have had important roles in the church's past, including Mary, saints, and lay executives, they are not allowed to be ordained as priests or become pope. However, some believe that a female pope may have existed in the medieval era, and movies have been made about the story of Pope Joan.

A Maryland man who received a kidney transplant in 2011 has died of rabies, which he contracted from the donor. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) said three other patients who received organs from the same donor are now being treated with anti-rabies shots. The CDC confirmed the Maryland man's death and determined the donor had died of the same type of rabies, which is spread by raccoons. The recipients' doctors were shocked to learn the donor's organs were tainted with rabies. However, organ donors are not routinely tested for rabies, and new rules need to be put in place to help doctors decide what to do with organs when the donor has died of encephalitis of unknown origin.

The CNN special on atheism did not feature enough people of color, as African-American atheists, despite being a growing segment, are still not well-represented in the community. The article argues that the religious culture in the black community makes it difficult for individuals to identify as atheists, and many may face ostracism as a result of their beliefs. The article also discusses the progress made in secular groups to increase diversity and representation, including support for the LGBT demographic and those from marginalized backgrounds. African-American atheists are determined to make their presence known and work towards change.

A ferry disaster in South Korea has left 228 people dead and 74 missing. Hundreds of family members of missing passengers gathered near a harbor in Jindo, waiting for news, but after officials said there were no more air pockets, the grim reality set in. The country's president, Park Geun-hye, apologized for the disaster and the government arrested three people on suspicion of destroying evidence. The South Korean authorities are investigating possible dereliction of duty and the impact of the disaster on the country's national psyche. About 70 survivors from the sunken ferry visited a memorial at Danwon High School in Ansan, the school that sent 325 students on a field trip. The survivors' visit was emotional, with many students sobbing as they walked past images of their classmates.

BP, the UK-based oil and gas company, claims to have implemented the most advanced safety systems for offshore drilling, according to the company's president of operations in the Gulf of Mexico. To prevent a repeat of the Deepwater Horizon disaster that caused a massive oil spill in 2010, BP has restructured its operations and invested in new technology. The company is also setting up a training facility to teach engineers and supervisors how to manage potential leaks. BP's new safety procedures will not directly impact the civil trial over the spill, but the company is trying to improve its image by highlighting profound changes in its practices. BP is the largest producer of oil and gas in the Gulf of Mexico and is facing challenges in other parts of the world. The aftermath of the Deepwater Horizon disaster still affects the company's prospects, including debarment from new federal contracts.

Lt. Gen. Karl Eikenberry, a military officer, is seeking approval to become the next U.S. Ambassador to Afghanistan. However, Afghanistan is designated as an "unaccompanied post" by the State Department due to the dangers of the war and terror attacks, which means family members are not allowed. Eikenberry wishes to bring his wife with him, but this request could collide with State Department rules. Sen. John Kerry, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, expressed his support for the idea, which would be a strong boost of morale for the Embassy. Eikenberry awaits Senate confirmation.

First Lady Michelle Obama will campaign in Iowa for Democratic candidate Bruce Braley, who seeks the open Senate seat currently held by retiring Sen. Tom Harkin. Braley is running against Republican state Sen. Joni Ernst, who has been endorsed by numerous high-profile Republicans, including Mitt Romney and Sarah Palin. Braley is attempting to paint Ernst as an extremist and has a low approval rating in Iowa. Michelle Obama's visit to Iowa comes as the President's approval rating in the state is below the national average. Other Democrats, including Bill and Hillary Clinton, will also campaign in Iowa this weekend.

Three DEA agents are under investigation for allegedly soliciting sex in Cartagena, Colombia, potentially exposing themselves to blackmail by drug cartels or other criminals. A government source said one agent had a long-term relationship with a prostitute. The scandal comes as the Secret Service is already embroiled in a prostitution scandal after an agent reportedly paid for sex in Colombia before President Obama's visit. The DEA agents were not involved in the president's security, but their behavior raises concerns about blackmail and compromising their mission. The Secret Service agent who reported the incident is on administrative leave, but not expected to lose his job. The scandals will be the subject of a Senate committee hearing.

Anes Subasic, a Bosnian-born U.S. citizen, was found guilty on terrorism charges including conspiracy to murder, kidnap, and injure people overseas, and conspiring to provide material support to terrorists. He was convicted along with six other men from North Carolina, who were led by Daniel Boyd, who pleaded guilty to conspiring to kill people abroad and providing material support to terrorists. Two of Boyd's sons also pleaded guilty and are in prison. The group, which operated from November 2006 until at least July 2009, provided money, weapons training, transportation, and personnel to "advance violent jihad." Subasic was part of a conspiracy to commit violent acts against U.S. service members and others abroad, said John Khin, an official with the Defense Criminal Investigative Service. An eighth man, Jude Kenan Mohammad, is also charged in the terror conspiracy and is believed to be in Pakistan or may have died.

A group of men in British Columbia hoisted a woman in a wheelchair over the railing of a bridge and let go. She bounced up and down over an icy river, strapped in her wheelchair, her blond hair flying. The woman won a charity contest sponsored by an adventure company that helps people with disabilities achieve their extreme sport dreams. Rougoor, who has been paralyzed since a motocross accident in 2008, won the trip by submitting a video of her shooting guns, riding high-tech bikes for paraplegics, and playing tennis in her wheelchair. The group encourages people with mobility issues to take extreme sports, saying it's perfectly safe. Rougoor said the bungee jump was liberating and plans to do it again.

The 2014 midterm elections resulted in a historic victory for Republicans, who won the largest congressional majority since World War II. On the individual level, many historic firsts were achieved, including Tim Scott becoming the first African-American senator elected in the South since Reconstruction and the first African-American to be elected to both the House and Senate. Mia Love became the first black Republican woman elected to Congress, while Joni Ernst became the first woman elected to represent Iowa in either house of Congress and the first female combat veteran elected to the Senate. Shelley Moore Capito won the Senate seat for West Virginia, becoming the first woman elected to the Senate from her state. Tom Cotton was elected as the first Iraq War and Afghanistan veteran to serve in the Senate. North Carolina's Senate race set a record for the most expensive race in U.S. history, with outside groups spending over $81 million. The number of women in Congress will reach 100 for the first time in history, and Gina Raimondo will become Rhode Island's first female governor. Elise Stefanik, at 30, became the youngest woman elected to Congress, representing New York's 21st Congressional District.

Thailand lifted a 60-day state of emergency that had been in effect in Bangkok and surrounding areas, giving the tourism industry hope that lagging arrival numbers will improve. The state of emergency was replaced with the Internal Security Act (ISA), which will be in effect until April 30. The ISA is considered less severe and still gives authorities power to impose curfews, set up checkpoints, and restrict the movement of demonstrators. The Bangkok Post reports the ISA is needed to maintain law and order during the Senate election on March 30 and reruns of the general election, expected in April. The caretaker government said the decision to lift the state of emergency a few days early was designed to reverse the negative impact Thailand's political crisis has had on the country's tourism industry and overall economy. Tourism industry expected to recover quickly.

The Department of Defense created the precursor to the internet with the goal of creating a communications system that could endure catastrophic disasters. The internet was designed to have no central point of failure, allowing anyone to run their own communications channel. Today, services built on that network, such as Twitter, have been used for rescue efforts and fundraising during the Haiti earthquake and other disasters. However, when Twitter was offline for 90 minutes recently, technology pundits began worrying about the weaknesses of having a single point of failure for critical communications. The reality is that organizations and individuals can use their own websites to relay critical information, rather than relying on a single company. In fact, the internet was designed to be decentralized, with the promise of stopping the reliance on individual companies as gatekeepers for communication. Companies such as Facebook and Google have stepped up to help people communicate, but the web is bigger than any one site or social network. The key lesson to learn from Twitter being down is that some needs are too important to put in the hands of any single company, and social networks come and go. The reality is that people can run their own websites and keep control over how they communicate.

In the Italian region of Abruzzo, the village of Santo Stefano di Sessanio was in danger of reverting to its wild past. However, the area is now transformed into a high-end resort through blending in with the surroundings, using the unspoiled landscape. Sextantio di Sessanio, a 29-year-old businessman Daniele Kihlgren, an Italian-Swedish businessman, Swedish businessman, an Italian

Robert Plant and Alison Krauss, the lead singer of Led Zeppelin and the golden girl of bluegrass, won five Grammy awards for their unlikely collaboration, "Raising Sand." However, both are 60 years old and have a lifetime ban on the mention of their names in the newspaper. Alison Krauss's name in the same time. The pair is 28 years old and has a lifetime ban on the mention of the duo is 30 years old and has a lifetime ban on the mention of the duo is 30 years old and has a lifetime ban on the mention of the duo is 30 years old and has a lifetime ban on the mention of a lifetime ban on the duo is 30 years old and has a lifetime ban on the lifetime ban on the lifetime ban on the topic and.

Cliven Bundy is a 67-year-old Nevada rancher who owes the U.S. government over $1 million in unpaid grazing fees. He refuses to pay and has been holding out for over 20 years. Federal officials arrived to round up his cattle for illegal grazing on public lands. He claims to be a hero who hails from a long family of ranchers.

President Obama will hold a meeting with top congressional leaders from both parties on Tuesday to discuss the war in Afghanistan. The administration is conducting a review of its Afghan strategy, and opposition Republicans are pushing for a rapid increase in troop levels. The president wants to hear from the leaders before making a decision. General Stanley McChrystal has submitted an assessment, saying he needs additional forces to carry out the counterinsurgency strategy successfully. Otherwise, the mission could fail, bringing a return of power to the Taliban. The White House has yet to respond to McChrystal's report, prompting accusations of indecisiveness and playing politics that puts U.S. soldiers on the ground at risk. Some in Obama's inner circle, including Vice President Joe Biden, are advocating a counterterrorism approach that focuses on combating al Qaeda through the use of unmanned drones and special forces. Eight American troops and two Afghan security force members were killed in a battle on Saturday.

A Gaza resident, Said Durrah, has many relatives in the Palestinian territory and can't count them all. Every explosion in Gaza feels personal to him. The recent conflict between Israel and Hamas in Gaza resulted in the death of a family of 10, which Durrah learned he was distantly related to. A cease-fire has provided some comfort, but it won't be lasting as it returns to the status quo, and the Palestinians have to rebuild their homes without any means to do so. The conflict has shifted the balance of power and is a central issue for Arab-Americans. The blockade of Gaza, backed by the United States, has created humanitarian concerns in Gaza, and many Arab-Americans say Gaza is under Israeli occupation. However, Durrah's family received a phone call from relatives in Rimal, Gaza, who were afraid as they don't know what tomorrow brings. They may not be able to sleep because of a cricket in the room, but Gazans are trying to sleep through the soundtrack of blasts and missiles. This month's exchange of Hamas rockets and Israeli airstrikes has prompted pro-Palestinian and pro-Israel rallies throughout the United States. The violence has prompted an outpouring of humanitarian aid to the people of Gaza, and more than 500 Palestinian-Americans, other Arab-Americans, Muslims, and others attended a vigil in front of the Dearborn City Hall in support of the Palestinians.
Rivalries

The father of George Zimmerman, the man accused of shooting and killing an unarmed black teen, has given a new twist to the story. Robert Zimmerman has claimed that his son was defending himself against Trayvon Martin, who had threatened to kill him and then beat him so badly that he had to shoot him. The elder Zimmerman vehemently defended his son's actions and disputed the account given by Martin's family attorney and legal experts. He also said that his son is colorblind and would not profile anyone based on their race. The case has sparked outrage throughout the nation and has led to a federal investigation, with President Obama calling it a tragedy. The case has also ignited protests and calls for Zimmerman's arrest.
Chuck Hagel Hagel was doomed defenses. Hagel was, undeter

Alan Alda, an actor and host of "Scientific American Frontiers," shares his personal experiences and reflections on life in his new book, "Things I Overheard While Talking to Myself." After nearly dying in 2003, Alda became more interested in finding meaning in life and exploring the existential questions that he and other existentialist philosophers pondered. He includes his thoughts on his life and career, his fears, and the examples set by his colleagues in his book. Alda also uses these experiences to encourage others to be rigorous in their pursuit of truth and to appreciate the importance of science in our lives.

A computer virus has infected the cockpits of America's Predator and Reaper drones, logging pilots' every keystroke while they remotely fly missions over Afghanistan and other warzones. The virus was first detected nearly two weeks ago by the military's Host-Based Security System, but it has not prevented pilots at Creech Air Force Base in Nevada from flying their missions overseas. However, the virus has resisted multiple efforts to remove it from Creech's computers, network security specialists say. It's not known exactly how far the virus has spread or who introduced it, but military network security specialists aren't sure whether it was introduced intentionally or by accident. The virus may be a common piece of malware that just happened to make its way into these sensitive networks. The infection raises the possibility that secret data may have been captured by the keylogger and then transmitted over the public internet to someone outside the military chain of command. Despite the security risks, drones have become America's tool of choice in both its conventional and shadow wars, allowing U.S. forces to attack targets and spy on its foes without risking American lives.

Australia has won its second gold medal at the London Olympics, with Tom Slingsby taking the top spot in the sailing event. However, the country has been struggling to meet expectations in the pool, with only one gold medal and disappointing performances from swimmers like James Magnussen. The lackluster performance has led to an identity crisis in Australia, with critics blaming the media for its negative coverage and placing too much emphasis on winning gold. Sailor Mitchell Watt criticized the media for portraying silver and bronze medals as disappointing, while swimmer Sally Pearson and hurdler Mitchell Watt have also expressed their frustration with the public's reaction to the team's performance. To prevent another national humiliation at the Commonwealth Games in two years, Swimming Australia has commissioned a review led by former national head coach Bill Sweetenham and Olympian Suzie O'Neill. The review aims to identify the reason for the team's poor performance in London and find ways to prevent it from happening again. The review will also look into issues such as team unity, pre-event tweeting, work ethic, and the possibility of bearded swimmers being forced to shave. Olympic swimmer Sam Stosur, who was bundled out in the first round of the Australian Open after her US Open victory, has also experienced the impact of high expectations. Meanwhile, Australian Olympic Committee President John Coates believes the solution to the problem is not necessarily more funding but reintroducing compulsory school sports. However, International Olympic Committee member Kevin Gosper disagrees, saying that funding is the difference between gold and silver.

The Kansas City Royals, who had a great run from 1976 to 1985, ended their 29-year drought in the World Series by defeating the Baltimore Orioles in the American League Championship Series. The Royals' success can be attributed to their strong defense, smart draft picks, and nifty trades, as their star players are not well-known outside of the baseball world. The team has also shown resilience, rallying from a 35-game stretch where they made 35 errors to win 11 straight games in the postseason. Former Royal Bo Jackson praised the team for their enjoyment of the game and lack of pressure, while former player George Brett, a fan favorite, said that the Royals have "been around so long, they're like a family." The Royals have advanced to the World Series for the first time since 1985, and they are ready to bring the title back to Kansas City.

In 2010, William Darelle Smith was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to life in prison. However, his conviction was recently overturned by the state's Supreme Court due to a juror's improper communication with a key prosecution witness, Dr. Adele Lewis, the medical examiner who testified. The juror, identified as Glenn Scott Mitchell, sent a laudatory message to Dr. Lewis on Facebook during the trial, saying she did a great job on the witness stand. The trial court did not hold a hearing to address this communication, and the appeals court ruled that it was just "mere interactions." However, the state Supreme Court overruled this decision and concluded that the trial court should have taken steps to assure that the juror had not been exposed to extraneous information or had not been improperly influenced. The court stressed that the trial court should have held a hearing to address the issue and that trial courts should give jurors specific, understandable instructions that prohibit extrajudicial communications with third parties and the use of technology to obtain facts that have not been presented as evidence.

A group of 1,253 people dressed in blue gathered in County Monaghan, Ireland, to set a record for the largest gathering of Smurfs. A 7-year-old boy from Michigan made a ball of plastic wrap that's 11 feet across. Anthony Victor of India has hair measuring 7.12 inches sprouting from the center of his outer ears, while 13-year-old Brenden Adams of Ellensburg, Washington, is having a hard time fitting into cars. Adams, who stands at 7 feet 4.6 inches tall, is now in the Guinness World Records 2010 book as the tallest teenage boy. The book also includes records on the most balloons inflated with a nose, longest fingernails, and largest ball of plastic wrap. Guinness World Records spokesman Stuart Claxton said, "We're intrigued by extremes in our daily life and by things we're not familiar with."

In March 2004, four Blackwater contractors were ambushed and killed in Fallujah, Iraq. Their bodies were burned, beaten, and dragged through the streets, where they were hung from a bridge for the cheering crowd to see. The incident sparked a U.S. military assault on the city. The four men's families were informed by U.S. marshals or sheriff's deputies, with Erik Prince, the founder of Blackwater, personally informing Jerry Zovko's parents in Cleveland, Ohio. This tragedy led to the formation of the private military company, Blackwater, which later became known as Academi.

Two years after his death, Michael Jackson's legacy remains a subject of debate. The Los Angeles coroner ruled that a surgical anesthetic called Propofol killed the singer, in combination with several sedatives found in his blood. Since then, there have been efforts to keep his memory and music alive, including a $275 million estate, a Cirque du Soleil show, and a new album. However, there are also legal entanglements surrounding his death, including a lawsuit filed by his mother and a wrongful death lawsuit filed by his father. Despite this, people continue to make money off of Jackson, including investors who plan to use a sale of photos to fund a motor that generates more electricity than it uses. In a rare public appearance, two of Jackson's children accepted a Lifetime Achievement Award on his behalf at the Grammy Awards.

The "nuclear option" refers to changing the Senate's rules to require only 51 votes for confirming judicial and executive nominees, instead of the current 60 votes. This would fundamentally change the character of the chamber, allowing the majority party to confirm nominees with a simple majority. The move has been controversial, with some arguing that it would undermine the minority party's ability to block legislation. However, the Constitution does not specify the rules for Senate proceedings, leaving the power to determine rules in the hands of senators. The use of the filibuster, which requires 60 votes to limit debate, has been a point of contention for years, with some arguing that it has been abused. The current fight is centered on the D.C. Circuit Court, but it extends beyond that, with both parties accusing the other of abusing the filibuster.

According to relationship advice columnist Deborrah Cooper, the devout follower of the Christian faith, Patty Davis, a 46-year-old Georgia native, attends bible study each Wednesday and Sunday's and is a weathered skins toned in black woman who is not religious, 558 years old, a 1989

Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee is releasing a new book, "God, Guns, Grits and Gravy," as he prepares for a potential 2016 presidential run. The book covers a wide range of topics, including his opinions on pop culture, government surveillance, and gay marriage. Huckabee is known for his Conservative views and is not a fan of reality television or Rihanna's style. He compares government without checks and balances to "Ferris Bueller's Day Off on steroids." Huckabee is also not pleased with outside conservative groups that he views as "pay for play." He has positive things to say about some potential 2016 opponents, but has no mention of Senators Marco Rubio, Ted Cruz, or Rand Paul and implicitly knocks the prospect that they all might run for president while serving in the Senate. The book also includes his thoughts on the Obamas' parenting skills and his allergy to cigarette smoke.

The Islamic State (ISIS) is actively recruiting young Americans to join their cause in Syria and Iraq, and some have already joined. This has raised concerns among officials as ISIS has been successful in Europe. Federal, state and local organizations, including law enforcement agencies, are working together to combat the threat. The situation is worrisome as young people are acquiring radicalized beliefs without committing crimes.

To prevent violent ideologies from taking root, countering violent extremism (CVE) is being used as a strategy. This involves engagement and partnership with communities, similar to community-oriented policing methods. The LAPD has established a Liaison Section of its Counter-Terrorism and Special Operations Bureau to improve public safety and build trust with diverse communities.

Community-led CVE initiatives, such as "Safe Spaces," are being rolled out across the US to increase Muslim-American communities' resilience against violent extremism. These initiatives teach helpful strategies to increase parental involvement and supportive adult mentorship for youth. Communities are also forming "crisis inquiry teams" to identify individuals believed to be at risk of engaging in violent beliefs and help them turn away from that path.

Opinion: The US government needs to build on the successes in these cities and learn from other countries such as Australia, Canada, and Britain. It is essential to increase knowledge of CVE strategies, accelerate implementation efforts, and measure the effectiveness of different CVE initiatives.

The newly elected head of Syria's opposition briefed European foreign ministers on the crisis in Syria, and they pledged support for the opposition. The EU foreign affairs representative Catherine Ashton met with Ahmed Moaz al-Khatib and warned that the world must take a stand against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad's actions. The EU expressed concern about the potential use and transfer of chemical weapons in Syria and warned that those responsible would be held accountable. Syria accused the United States of working to falsely accuse the country of using chemical weapons, and U.S. officials said they had seen intelligence suggesting that Syrian military units may be preparing chemical weapons for use. The United States and European allies are using defense contractors to train Syrian rebels to secure chemical weapons stockpiles. Fighting continued across the country, and at least 142 people died on Monday, including 59 in Aleppo and 50 in Damascus and its suburbs.

Two health care workers in Florida have been confirmed to have contracted MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome) after treating a patient who had flown in from Saudi Arabia. The patient is being treated at Dr. P. Phillips Hospital in Orlando, and officials are being cautious to prevent further spread of the virus. The two health care workers are being tested and are expected to be medically cleared to return to work in 14 days. The CDC and the Florida Department of Health are investigating the case and officials are urging the public to avoid unnecessary travel to the Arabian Peninsula and to wash their hands frequently.

In a surprise revelation, Mitt Romney's father was born in Chihuahua, Mexico, making the presumptive Republican presidential nominee half-Mexican. However, Romney has not publicly discussed this branch of his family tree, as he rarely talks about his Mexican heritage on the campaign trail. Despite this, he has criticized policies that help undocumented immigrants, which has made him unpopular among Latino voters. A recent poll found that only 23% of Latino voters would vote for him, while President Obama would easily win with 68%.

The US Senate rejected a House budget plan that included a controversial provision to overhaul Medicare and also unanimously voted down President Barack Obama's 2012 budget proposal. The vote was seen as a political theater rather than a legislative action. Republicans who opposed the Medicaid overhaul proposal were joined by three Democrats who opposed the proposal. The vote on the proposal was 57-40, mostly along party lines. The Medicare overhaul plan would start in 2022 and would rework the government-run health insurance program for senior citizens. Democrats argue that the Medicare overhaul would cost senior citizens an average of roughly $6,000 more per year for health care.

On Monday, rapper Dolla was gunned down in the parking lot of the Beverly Center mall in Los Angeles, California. Aubrey Louis Berry, 23, was arrested in connection with the murder. Dolla, whose real name was Roderick Anthony Burton II, was known for his kind and gracious nature despite coming from a difficult background. He was a protégé of singer Akon and was working on his debut album in Los Angeles. Dolla's family released a statement asking for privacy to mourn their loss. The motive for the murder is still unknown. The news of Dolla's death is a tragic reminder of the violence associated with the hip-hop industry.
